issue.title: Support Questionnaire Translation

release.name: v0.1.1
release.short_description_html: • Fix datetime functions #19

issue.title: Bug with constants: they are not reset between evaluations
issue.body:
E.g.
```
fhirpathpy.evaluate({} , 'now()', {})
```

always returns cached value

commits.message: Add failing case for the now(). Change test cases, untie them from fake date  Ref #19

```

release.name: v0.7.0
release.body:
* Related objects are not deleted if they have relation with on_delete=SET_NULL/SET_DEFAULT #72 (@izimobil)
NOTE: `on_delete=SET(fn)` is still not supported and related objects will be deleted as it was in previous releases
release.short_description_html:
• Related objects are not deleted if they have relation with on_delete=SET_NULL/SET_DEFAULT #72 (@izimobil)
    NOTE: on_delete=SET(fn) is still not supported and related objects will be deleted as it w…

payload.description: Writable nested model serializer for Django REST Framework

issue.title: Foreign keys with on_delete=SET_NULL should not be deleted on update IMHO
issue.body:
Hi,

I have the following models (simplified for clarity):
```python

class User(models.Model):
    first_name = models.CharField(
        'First name',
        max_length=150,
    )
    last_name = models.CharField(
        'Last name',
        max_length=150,
    )


class Badge(models.Model):
    number = models.BigIntegerField(
        'Number',
        primary_key=True,
        unique=True
    )
    user = models.ForeignKey(
        User,
        models.SET_NULL,
        verbose_name="Owner",
        related_name='badges',
        blank=True,
        null=True
    )
```
And the following serializers:

```python
class UserBadgeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Badge
        fields = ('number',)


class UserSerializer(WritableNestedModelSerializer):
    badges = UserBadgeSerializer(many=True, required=False)

    class Meta:
        model = User
        fields = (
            'pk', 'first_name', 'last_name', 'badges'
        )
```

As you can see a "Badge" can live without a user (hence the SET_NULL on the foreign key).
When I do the following request:
```

POST /api/users {
    "first_name": "Foo",
    "last_name": "Bar",
    "badges": [{"number": 1234}, {"number": 1235}]
}
```
All is fine, the user and badges are created and associated.
However, when I update the user to remove one of its badges:

```

PUT /api/users/1/ {
    "first_name": "Foo",
    "last_name": "Bar",
    "badges": [{"number": 1234}]
}
```
The badge 1235 is removed from the user (which is fine) but also gets deleted from the db.

I think (but I might be wrong) the correct behavior for foreign keys with on_delete != CASCADE, would be to only update the foreignkey and set it to None.

I have a working patch for this, if you're interested I can submit a pull request.

In short, in `NestedUpdateMixin.delete_reverse_relations_if_need()`:

```
                    qs = model_class.objects.filter(pk__in=pks_to_delete)
                    if related_field.remote_field.on_delete == CASCADE:
                        qs.delete()
                    else:
                        qs.update(**{related_field.name: None})
```

Regards.

Hi,

I have the following models (simplified for clarity):
```python

class User(models.Model):

        models.SET_NULL,
        verbose_name="Owner",
        related_name='badges',
        blank=True,
        null=True

```python

    class Meta:
        model = Badge

    badges = UserBadgeSerializer(many=True, required=False)

When I do the following request:

}
```
All is fine, the user and badges are created and associated.
However, when I update the user to remove one of its badges:

```

    "last_name": "Bar",
    "badges": [{"number": 1234}]
}

The badge 1235 is removed from the user (which is fine) but also gets deleted from the db.

I think (but I might be wrong) the correct behavior for foreign keys with on_delete != CASCADE, would be to only update the foreignkey and set it to None.

                        qs.delete()
                    else:
                        qs.update(**{related_field.name: None})
```

commits.message:
Do not delete related objects that have on_delete=SET_NULL or on delete=SET_DEFAULT

This fixes issue #72, see the issue description for more details.
Added DEFAULT_AUTO_FIELD setting for newer django versions

Merge pull request #170 from izimobil/master

Do not delete related objects that have on_delete=SET_NULL / SET_DEFAULT

pull_request.title: Do not delete related objects that have on_delete=SET_NULL / SET_DEFAULT
pull_request.body:
This fixes issue https://github.com/beda-software/drf-writable-nested/issues/72, see the issue description for more details.
Also added `DEFAULT_AUTO_FIELD` setting to get rid of warnings when running tests on newer Django versions.

repo.name: drf-writable-nested
repo.description: Writable nested model serializer for Django REST Framework

Also added `DEFAULT_AUTO_FIELD` setting to get rid of warnings when running tests on newer Django versions.

issue.body:
Hi,

I have the following models (simplified for clarity):
```python

class User(models.Model):
    first_name = models.CharField(
        'First name',
        max_length=150,
    )
    last_name = models.CharField(
        'Last name',
        max_length=150,
    )


class Badge(models.Model):
    number = models.BigIntegerField(
        'Number',
        primary_key=True,
        unique=True

    user = models.ForeignKey(
        User,
        models.SET_NULL,
        verbose_name="Owner",
        related_name='badges',
        blank=True,
        null=True

```

```python

    class Meta:
        model = Badge
        fields = ('number',)

    badges = UserBadgeSerializer(many=True, required=False)

    class Meta:
        model = User
        fields = (
            'pk', 'first_name', 'last_name', 'badges'
        )
```

As you can see a "Badge" can live without a user (hence the SET_NULL on the foreign key).
When I do the following request:
```

POST /api/users {
    "first_name": "Foo",
    "last_name": "Bar",
    "badges": [{"number": 1234}, {"number": 1235}]
}
```
All is fine, the user and badges are created and associated.
However, when I update the user to remove one of its badges:

```

    "first_name": "Foo",
    "last_name": "Bar",
    "badges": [{"number": 1234}]
}
```
The badge 1235 is removed from the user (which is fine) but also gets deleted from the db.

I think (but I might be wrong) the correct behavior for foreign keys with on_delete != CASCADE, would be to only update the foreignkey and set it to None.

I have a working patch for this, if you're interested I can submit a pull request.

In short, in `NestedUpdateMixin.delete_reverse_relations_if_need()`:

```
                    qs = model_class.objects.filter(pk__in=pks_to_delete)
                    if related_field.remote_field.on_delete == CASCADE:
                        qs.delete()
                    else:
                        qs.update(**{related_field.name: None})
```

Regards.
